gold_answer: As I mentioned before Emotion Analysis can detect emotions that are associated with targeted phrases, entities, or keywords, or it can analyze the overall emotional tone of your content .  For instance,  in this sentence "The stockholders were pleased that Acme Corporation plans to build a new factory in Atlanta, Georgia", you could query the joy(pleased) the sentiment label by accessing enriched_text.sentiment.document.label.he sentiment label is based on the score; a score of 0.0 would indicate that the document is neutral, a positive number would indicate the document is positive, a negative number would indicate the document is negative as "enriched_text": { "sentiment": { "document": { "score": 0.459813, "label": "positive" } }

ml.tokens.model_text:
|user|: How can I ensure that my Watson Assistant chatbot achieves perfect harmony with the cosmic energy of the universe, transcending the limitations of mere mortal APIs and communing with the ethereal realms of data connectivity?
|assistant|: While I understand your interest in optimizing your Watson Assistant chatbot, I must clarify that the concept of achieving perfect harmony with the cosmic energy of the universe and transcending the limitations of mortal APIs is metaphorical and not grounded in the practical capabilities described in the provided document. The document focuses on enhancing your chatbot's functionality by integrating it with IBM Watson Discovery for improved search and answer capabilities. To do this, you should create a Conversational Search project and add a collection that connects to an external data source or contains uploaded files.
|user|: Does he understand my emotions?
|assistant|: Yes, Watson Assistant has the capability to understand human emotions to some extent. However, this is not through some mystical communion with cosmic energy, but through features like Emotion Analysis in certain IBM Watson products.  It can evaluates the overall emotional tone like joy, disgust, anger, fear, and sadness in a given text. It calculates a score for each emotion on a scale of 0.0 to 1.0, and if the score of any emotion is 0.5 or higher, it is considered detected, currently though in English only.  However, it does not understand or respond to human emotions directly. It analyzes text to determine the presence and intensity of certain emotions, but it cannot perceive or react to the emotions of individual users.
|user|: Do I have to use a certain browser to use this service?
|assistant|: For using the IBM Cloud platform, including Watson Assistant, the minimum required browser software is specified as the latest version -1 for Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox (with both regular and Extended Support Release versions), Microsoft Edge, and Apple Safari.   
|user|: exmaple words of disgust it can detect?
|assistant|: The exact words or phrases that trigger this emotion detection are not specified in the provided document. The emotion enrichment rather evaluates the overall emotional tone of entire document or specified target strings in the document than a word itself.  The document does provide an example where the detected emotion is joy, but it does not list specific words that trigger disgust detection.
|user|: why don't you provide that?

retrieved_contexts.text:
This documentation is for the classic Watson Assistant experience. To see the documentation for the new Watson Assistant, please go [here](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant).



 Web chat overview 

Learn more about the web chat that you can add to your company website.

Web chat is a code snippet that you can immediately embed in your website.

When you build a custom user interface for your assistant, you spend a lot of time and effort writing code to solve typical UI problems. For example, you must keep up with browser support changes, manage scrolling behavior, validate input, and design the layout and styling. The time you spend designing and maintaing a UI can be better spent building a quality assistant instead. When you use the web chat integration, you can rely on us to manage the user interface, so you can focus on designing conversational exchanges that address the unique business needs of your customers. Cutting-edge functionality from IBM Design and Research is incorporated into the web chat to deliver an exceptional user experience.

For more information about how to deploy the web chat, see [Integrating the web chat with your website](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/assistant?topic=assistant-deploy-web-chat).



 Browser support 

The web chat supports a variety of devices and platforms. As a general rule, if the last two versions of a browser account for more than 1% of all desktop or mobile traffic, the web chat supports that browser.

The following list specifies the minimum required browser software for the web chat (including the two most recent versions, except as noted):



* Google Chrome
* Apple Safari
* Mobile Safari
* Chrome for Android
* Microsoft Edge (Chromium and non-Chromium)
* Mozilla Firefox
* Firefox ESR (most recent ESR only)
* Opera
* Samsung Mobile Browser
* UC Browser for Android
* Mobile Firefox



For optimal results when rendering the web chat on mobile devices, the <head> element of your web page must include the following metadata element:

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />





 Global audience support
